reviewText: I can't add to anything to how good this show was! I have bootleg copiesI bought years ago and since the reviews of quality aren't better I'llwait to buy at cheaper price! I do have issue with why Roger Davis isn'tfeature on cover! He was Hannibal Heyes for many episodes and many of usfans liked him! I was shocked and sad at Duel's death but the show wasso well written and acted it was hard not to like Davis! He actually lookedmore like Kid Curry's cousin than Duel did! They could've had Heyes killedand made him another character it might have made people accept Davis. Hewas in some classic episodes just as good as Duel. Too bad it didn't lastlonger. I would say i'd love to see a remake but it would be as bad as allthe remakes they make today! Nightstalker? Hawaii five-0? Charlies Angels?there are no writers or actors with enough skills to do it justice!

Title: N/A

reviewText: 3.5 stars. While I'm glad to have the rest of this series, and while the episodes are watchable in terms of sound and picture quality, they were not cleaned up much, if at all (I am watching on a 42 inch LCD). I got my set for less than $20 at Sam's and so feel like I got a good deal in terms of what I paid. But I am disappointed in the picture quality overall. Though they cram a lot of episodes on each disc (and it is strange that the discs are not numbered), compression doesn't seem the big problem (slow drifting smoke doesn't present a lot of artifacts)--the problem is less-than-pristine prints. If you're a fan of the series, I'd recommend paying no more than $20 because the picture quality doesn't warrant more. But great to have these wonderful shows. This set isn't bad, and it's certainly better than having nothing, it's just hard to go from the season one set to this for me personally.
summary: Picture quality not as good as season one set
Title: N/A

reviewerName: D. S. Wymore "Golden Age of Hollywood fan"
reviewText: Five stars for the television show; 1 star for the packaging!  Alias Smith and Jones is my favorite television show of all time and has been since I was 15. I haven't seen any of the episodes since they originally aired in 1971 so it was wonderful to view them all over again. Since I was a teenager at the time, I didn't realize how many stars from the Golden Age of Hollywood appeared on the show (Rudy Vallee, George Montgomery, Walter Brennan, Craig Stevens, Don Ameche, Cesar Romero, etc... - each a delight to see).  I could go on and on with my thoughts about the program but I think this space is better used to say a few things about the DVD product itself. First: the print used of "The Day They Hanged Kid Curry" is not up to snuff. It's faded, has bad color balance and a lot of dirt and scratches. However, you have to bear in mind that this episode was probably supposed to air twice and, due to length, probably not in syndication. Therefore, the original print was probably not maintained as pristine as the rest of the series. Second: whoever wrote the liner notes on the back of the DVDs obviously never watched the show, nor did the person who proofread the liner prior to going to print. If they had watched the show, they would know that Roger Davis replaced Pete Duel as the Hannibal Heyes character (NOT Kid Curry), as written on the liner notes of Disc 4, episode 2 (The Biggest Game in the West).  Third: the packaging itself is very bare bones - no extras, no fun photos, no interviews and the box itself is flimsy. It would've made the DVD set a little extra special  if there was an interview with Ben Murphy and Roger Davis. What a missed opportunity! Forth: Academy Award winner Anne Baxter is NOT in the episode Shootout at Diablo Station as indicated on the liner notes - it is Anne Archer. Timeless Video/ Universal Studios/ NBC - you ought to be embarrassed! That  liner notes writer and proofreader need to be reassigned to different jobs - or maybe even fired.
summary: My favorite TV show ever! But slipshod packaging - Many Mistakes!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am also very happy they finally released the rest of the series. It is great to have them on dvd. I wanted to respond to one reviewer who said "The Day They Hanged Kid Curry" may not have a cleaned up print like the rest of the series that ran on encore a few years back. I have a beautiful copy of that extended episode taped off encore westerns about 15 to 20 years ago. Believe me it is far superior to what was released on this dvd set. Also the episodes while not bad quality are not as good as the ones I have taped off encore. I applaud timeless for releasing this gem to the fans but lets face it they are not the best at remastering old tv shows to dvd. Look at some of the "Checkmate" and "Riverboat" shows they have released and you will see what I mean. AS&J was such a great show probably the last really good tv western to come from the networks and it deserved a top notch release.

Title: N/A

reviewText: I loved Alias Smith and Jones very much at the time, but the death of Pete Duel was a real blow.  The Men That Corrupted Hadleyburg (Episode 18 of Season 2) was Pete Duel's last episode.  The show was never the same after that.  Roger Davis tried his best to replace Pete but to no avail.  It is nice to have all the series available on disc now, butSeason Oneis the set to get, which has 15 great episodes with Pete Duel and Ben Murphy as one of the most appealing pair of robbers sinceButch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.
summary: The show was never the same without Pete Duel

reviewText: I just bought this DVD set of Alias Smith and Jones season 2 and 3.  I have the first season and knew I would get the rest.  It is a great show.  One of my favorites.  I am a big Pete Duel fan.  So sad he died.  The show is great and I love the acton, the acting and everything about it.  BUT... YOU KNOW THAT WAS COMING. BUT... The packaging is horrible.  And there are no extras on it.  Not even a tribute to Pete Duel.  Even on the Gidget TV show  DVD Sally Fields talks about Pete Duel.  He was a regualar on that show also.  The box is flimsy and the cases are hard to get out.  This doesnt mean you should not  get it.  It is a GREAT SHOW. To bad Universal didn't release it.  Perhaps they didnt know all the loyal fans it has.  Now for the rest of the BUT.  After Pete Duel died, the show went down hill.  I like Roger Davis, but he is not right for the part for a number of reasns.  1.  He looks like Chuck Conners and I keep thinking of the Rifleman when seeing him.  2.  His looks are not a contrast to Ben Murphy, also a blond.  The show tries to make up for this by saying they are now cousins.  Doesnt work for me.  3.  Hannibal is suppose to be the brains of the two.  Roger  doesnt pull it off like Pete did.  Pete Duel had that con artist smile that told you he was pulling the wool over someone's eyes.  Plus Pete Duel was  a better actor then Roer Davis.  The show also tried to bring in a female quality near the end.  True, Sally Fields was in some of the early episodes, and was brought back, but trying to put Michelle Lee in as George didnt work for me.  She didnt have the same chemestry that Sally had with the two. When Sally Fields did come back she was in an episdoe called  "The Clementine Ingredient" which also had Alejandro  Rey in it.  As we all know the two stared in "The Flying Nun" for 3 years.  Seeing Sally and Alej kiss in this episode was a little ... well frightening. like Sister Bertrille kissing Carlos.

reviewText: The picture quality on some of the episodes was poor for a DVD.  I can only assume the source tape/film used to transfer to DVD was of poor quality.  At times the colors were washed out, light.  Picture occasionally smeared/jumped with head movement. I do realize that these DVD's were NOT advertised as being digitally remastered and that may be the difference.  The quality on the 2 hr movie was superb.  For the price, I think the set was OK.  Being a true western fan, I am still pleased with the DVD's.
Title: N/A

reviewText: We've been waiting a long time here in the UK for Seasons 2 and 3 and at long last they've arrived! Shame that Universal Playback didn't see fit to release them but all credit to Timeless Media. Hugely successful in the UK on first transmission and many re-runs, for some reason 'The Day They Hanged Kid Curry' was never broadcast here, and no reason ever given. Anyway, I was grateful for the chance to see the aformentioned episode for the first time, although I have to say the print quality is quite poor, as mentioned by another reviewer. This is in complete contrast to the other 34 episodes and I hope it doesn't put people off watching the rest, which are visually crisp, clean and with a top-quality soundtrack, despite being crammed onto 6 DVDs. Great bargain at the price. Highly recommended. I only hope that British fans pick up on the fact that a Region 1 release has happened; it may not make it to Region 2 but most UK DVD players are now multi-region so it shouldn't be a problem so long as people over here know the box-set exists! Great series, timeless (excuse the pun!) and great entertainment. Maybe I can dispense with my carefully treasured off-air VHS episodes now...?
summary: At last - the rest of Alias Smith & Jones!

reviewerName: Wayne Klein "If at first the idea is not absu...
reviewText: 4 stars for series2 stars for presentation for the DVD-read below:"Alias Smith and Jones" chugged along like a locomotive at top speed starting as a TV movie and then turned into a midseason replacement. The show became so popular that ABC immediately renewed the series for season two. Sadly after shooting the 18th episode and while on break actor Pete Duel killed himself leaving the popular series without finished dialogue for some scenes (voice actor Paul Frees came in and dubbed Duel's voice for these scenes)and five episodes short of what was ordered. Actor Roger Davis (who had auditioned for Hannibal Heyes but lost the role to Duel ending up as the opening narrator for the series)replaced Duel for the remaining five episodes and the show--still popular although fans were still reeling from the death of Duel--was renewed for a third season.Sadly, the first season set didn't sell as well as Universal had hoped so they licensed it out to another company giving them access to the transfers that they had prepared for seasons two and three. One of the problems with a show licensed from a studio is that there isn't much money (or the company releasing it doesn't feel as if it is worthwhile to spend the money since they don't own the show)to clean up the series for home video.The image quality is fairly shoddy due to 1) overcompression (i.e., too many episodes per disc--six)and 2)the varying conditions of episodes (the two hour second season premiere looks like it was pulled from a 16mm syndication print and has black leader spliced in for missing frames as the fake Kid Curry is led to the gallows--although others look like they are from the 35mm but with no restoration/clean up). Skin tones are a bit too pink and colors are generally washed out looking. Blacks are crushed and detail is murky in many episodes.Aliasing is a problem through the set which wasn't as big an issue with the original Universal release of the first season. There's also plenty of video noise sprinkled throughout the set.The original mono audio sounds fine although it would have been nice to include closed captioning or subtitles as an option for the series for those members of the audience who are getting up there in years.It's a pity that there aren't any additional extras such as commentary tracks from those who worked on the show discussing the issues that dogged the series by the end of season two and the final season (I did my own podcast for the two hour movie second season premiere, the last episode with Duel and the first with Roger Davis as a gift to friends who had the set).It's too bad that Timeless didn't elect to put less episodes per disc (4 or 5 would have been the maximum)and that Universal didn't use the high def versions that aired on the Encore Western Channel as they looked better.
summary: Seminal series receives a shoddy transfer to DVD for seasons 2 & 3
